big_picture_notes: Amos is a rhetorically formal, tightly organized anthology that moves from Oracles Against the Nations (1:3–2:16) through three 'Hear this word' sermons (3:1; 4:1; 5:1) into five climactic visions (7:1–9; 8:1–3; 9:1–10), before a final unconditional restoration oracle (9:11–15). Literary glue includes the repeated OAN formula ('For three transgressions … and for four, I will not revoke the punishment'), refrain-like doxologies ('The LORD is his name' 4:13; 5:8; 9:6), and the progression from relented threats to irrevocable judgment. Genres interleave: oracles, woes, doxologies, and a prose confrontation (7:10–17). The book’s arc culminates in the raised 'booth of David' and abundant agricultural peace.

stories.story_title: The Ring of Judgment (Oracles Against the Nations)
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Unified by the OAN formula encircling Israel (Damascus → Philistia → Tyre → Edom → Ammon → Moab → Judah → Israel), climaxing in Israel’s detailed indictment and military collapse. Start (1:1): superscription; (1:2) roaring prelude. End (2:16): stout-hearted flee naked—closure of the OAN. Glue: repeated 'for three … and for four … I will not revoke' plus fire/exile sentences.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Superscription gives author/time; transition to oracle with 'The LORD roars from Zion'—lion/theophany imagery signaling judgment.
First OAN formula; crime: threshing Gilead; sentence: fire and exile to Kir. Devices: formulaic indictment/sentence.
Slave-trading to Edom condemned; four Philistine cities named for totality; ends with remnant perishing.
Violation of covenant of brotherhood; brief, staccato oracle; fire on Tyre’s wall.
Perpetual wrath against brother; sentence targets Teman/Bozrah; kinship betrayal motif.
Atrocity (ripping pregnant women) for border expansion; war tumult; king and princes exiled.
Desecration of a king’s bones; ruler and princes cut off; formula + fire sentence.
Legal/theological breach: rejected Yahweh’s law; palaces of Jerusalem consumed by fire.
Expanded indictment: selling the righteous, trampling poor, sexual impurity, profaning sanctuary; contrasts with Yahweh’s saving acts (Exodus, prophets, Nazirites).
Imagery of crushing/pressing; roles of swift/strong/mighty fail; flight naked—final OAN closure.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Three addresses marked by 'Hear this word' (3:1; 4:1; 5:1) move from covenant privilege and necessity of prophecy, to satire and repeated chastisements, to lament/ethical demands and woes. End (6:14): named foreign oppressor arises. Glue: refrain-like commands, doxology interruption, and anti-false security.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: 'Hear this word' opens; seven rhetorical questions climax in 'The Lord GOD has spoken; who can but prophesy?'—cause/effect logic.
Pagan witnesses summoned; accusation: oppression; results: ivory houses shattered, Bethel’s horns cut off.
Wealthy women mocked; hooks/exile imagery; concluding parody of cult highlights hypocrisy.
Refrain 'yet you did not return to me' structures five disciplines (famine, drought, blight/locust, pestilence/sword, overthrow); culminates in 'prepare to meet your God.'
Hymnic fragment interrupts: forms mountains, declares to man—'Yahweh, God of hosts, is his name!'

scenes.scene_name: Lament and Command to Seek God
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Elegy over fallen virgin Israel; exhortation to seek Yahweh, not Bethel/Gilgal/Beersheba; fire warning on Joseph’s house.
Turning justice to wormwood; taxing the poor; wise silent in evil time—framed indictment of civic corruption.
Brief exhortation to seek good; conditional grace; vision of universal wailing when Yahweh passes through.

scenes.scene_name: Woe to Those Who Desire the Day of Yahweh
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Refutes false eschatological optimism via lion/bear/serpent similes; day is darkness, not light.
'I hate your feasts' → demand for justice to roll; exile beyond Damascus for idolatry.
Ease in Zion/Samaria; luxury satire; first into exile—woe resolves in reversal of status.

scenes.scene_name: Oath and Final Threat in the Sermons
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Yahweh swears against pride; absurd proverbs (horses on rock) expose folly; oppressor nation raised from Hamath to Arabah.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Vision reports (7:1; 7:4; 7:7; 8:1; 9:1) progress from relented threats (locusts, fire) to no‑relent plumb line, basket/end pun, and the Lord at the altar. A prose interlude (7:10–17) authenticates Amos and announces Amaziah’s doom. Ends (9:10) with non‑escapable sword for all sinners. Glue: 'This is what the Lord GOD showed me' formula and escalating finality.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Locusts after first harvest; intercession 'How can Jacob stand?'; Yahweh relents—conditionality emphasized.
Cosmic fire devours deep/land; repeated intercession; Yahweh relents again—pattern set.
Measuring righteousness; 'I will not again pass by them'; high places and Jeroboam’s house targeted.
Prose confrontation validates divine commissioning; pronounces Amaziah’s personal doom; exile confirmed.
Wordplay qayits/qets (fruit/end); temple songs to wailing; corpses cast out in silence.
Hear this, tramplers of needy; cheating measures; oath by Pride of Jacob; land trembles—economic injustice oracle.
Sun at noon darkened; festivals to mourning; mourning like for an only son—cosmic/hymnic fragment.
Spiritual famine announced; futile north-south search; idolaters fall, never to rise—unique judgment type.

scenes.scene_name: Vision 5: The Lord by the Altar
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Command to strike the thresholds; inescapable pursuit (Sheol/heaven/sea); eye set for evil, not good.
He who touches the earth and it melts; builds upper chambers in the heavens—'Yahweh is his name!'
Rhetorical question levels Israel with nations; sifting metaphor spares grain but slays sinners by the sword—judgment closure.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Complete tonal reversal to unconditional restoration: rebuilding David’s fallen booth and overflowing agricultural blessing. Start (9:11): 'In that day I will raise up…' End (9:15): never uprooted. Glue: rebuild/plant/restore fortune motifs.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Raise/repair/rebuild contrasts fallen booth; aim: possess remnant of Edom and all called by Yahweh’s name. Devices: contrast, Davidic promise.

scenes.scene_name: Final Promises of Abundance and Security
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Plowman overtakes reaper; mountains drip sweet wine; fortunes restored; never uprooted—permanent tenure in land.
